Orson Welles, radio and stage actor, whose dramatization, Oct. 30, 1938 of an H. G. Wells novel titled “War of the Worlds” which related the “invasion” of New Jersey by a horde of men from mars was interpreted by listeners as an actual news broadcast. (Photo: AP) 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
More than 75 years ago, Orson Welles panicked America with his famous "War of the Worlds" radio broadcast. 
Aired as a Halloween episode of "Mercury Theatre on the Air" in 1938 (a year sandwiched between the Hindenburg explosion and the outbreak of World War II) the program was presented in a unique reality format, as a series of "breaking newsflashes." 
Martians had landed in the Trenton-area village of Grover's Mill, audiences learned. 
Orson Welles, center, explains to reporters on Oct. 31, 1938 his radio dramatization of H.G. Wells'"War of the Worlds." Meanwhile, Columbia Broadcasting System made public the transcript of the dramatization, which was aired the night of Oct. 30 and caused thousands of listeners to panic because of the realistic broadcast of an imaginative invasion of men and machines from Mars. (Photo: AP) 
With "death rays" of fire and poison gas, the invaders were attacking New Jersey, killing and burning, as they made their way toward New York City. 
Many anxious listeners, especially those who had tuned in late from the popular Charlie McCarthy program, missed announcements that the broadcast was a dramatization based on a Victorian-era H.G. Wells novel. 
Apparently, some people in the local region were swept up in the resulting waves of mass hysteria that urban legend has depicted as springing up that night. <!--iframe--> 
"Some thought the world was coming to an end, others prepared to flee for their lives and pray," stated an article in the next day's Vineland Evening Times. 
"Local police, newspaper offices and the telephone exchange answered scores of telephone calls last evening from excited residents into whose hearts terror was struck by a fantastic radio broad-cast ..." reported the Millville Daily Republican. 
According to local accounts, at least two alarmed Millville families were preparing to retreat into the marshes at East Point, and a nearby state police officer ordered road patrols to stand by for service in "stricken" areas. 
Orson Welles, left, photographed with Mr. H.G. Wells, Nov. 30, 1940. (Photo: AP) 
In Camden, meanwhile, residents fled to nearby farms "where they believed there would be less likelihood of being asphyxiated by the gas "used by the invaders. 
"We didn't hear anything about it being a fake," a Landis Township woman told reporters. "My children became hysterical and I thought I was going to have a heart attack. It was no joke." 
Joke or not, the scare would have at least one beneficial effect, surmised Vineland columnist Gordon J. Hart, in that it would stimulate interest in the "gripping tales" of H.G. Wells. Local History: Mystery of abducted boy remains unsolved 
It also proved a catalyst for the career of Orson Welles, who made his major motion picture debut with "Citizen Kane" in 1941. 
First known as a book, and then an infamous radio broadcast, "War of the Worlds" is probably best remembered today for its Hollywood screen adaptations. 
Most notable of these is the 1953 Technicolor spectacle starring Gene Barry and Ann Robinson, and Steven Spielberg's 2005 blockbuster starring Tom Cruise, in which both Barry and Robinson make a cameo appearance.
